name: (2E)-2-(1,3-benzothiazol-2-yl)-2-[(4-fluorophenyl)hydrazono]ethanamide
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1088

name: (2E)-2-(1,3-benzothiazol-2-yl)-2-[(4-fluorophenyl)hydrazono]ethanamide
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1088
Reason: The compound in question contains several functional groups which influence its melting point: - Basic benzothiazole unit: similar to benzene, with an expected base melting point of around 80°C for the aromaticity. - Benzothiazole nitrogen: +5-10°C, heteroatoms like nitrogen can form additional intermolecular forces, increasing the melting point. - Fluorobenzene unit: similar to benzene but the fluorine substitution can increase melting point due to the electronegativity of fluorine contributing to stronger intermolecular forces; estimated increase of around +20°C. - Hydrazono group (–NN=C–): +15°C for increased molecular complexity and ability to have hydrogen bonding or dipole interactions. - Amide (–CONH–): +40°C, amides participate in strong hydrogen bonding, significantly increasing the melting point. Adding these effects together gives us the predicted melting point.
